Anti-War Protesters Fight Military Recruiters in Schools
 "Before the school board could act on the request, she berated an Army recruiter who showed up at Garfield High, told the soldier he was not welcome and waved pictures of Iraq war casualties in his face.
 These guys are just doing their jobs and trying to serve their country. Good grief.

post_info.post_title: Is this REALLY an effective way to protest the war?

Kronus

These guys are just doing their jobs and trying to serve their country. Good grief.
 

 
 So what? If someone works for the government you're not supposed to say anything if you disagree with them? That's what freedom of speech is for, to let the government know if you don't like what it's doing.
jyoshu

So what? If someone works for the government you're not supposed to say anything if you disagree with them? That's what freedom of speech is for, to let the government know if you don't like what it's doing.

 
 I didn't say she shouldn't be able to. The question at the the top of the forum is 'is this an EFFECTIVE way to protest the war'. If you think it is, then tell me why. I don't think these parents realize that there's really no difference between what they're doing by protesting recruiters, and going out on the battlefield and protesting at the soldiers there. Both are simply doing their duty.
georged

Effective? Both volunteered to perform that duty or face prison, which makes them responsible parties, the recruiter in particular. She should travel to Iraq? 
 
 Since right to assemble has been redefined by government to a location disallowing voice contact of public protest to public officials, I'd think she actually wanted someone representing her government to hear her protest.
georged
And it does bring Vietnam to mind, when public officials shielded themselves from protest and citizenry eventually vented their frustrations on the troops.
Kronus

I didn't say she shouldn't be able to. The question at the the top of the forum is 'is this an EFFECTIVE way to protest the war'. 

 
 I know what your title is. I also note that nothing in your post addresses that question. All you do is imply that, because they're "doing their duty", there's something wrong with protesting recruiters. I'm address the contents of your post, not the title of it, which you also ignore.
daewoo

I didn't say she shouldn't be able to. The question at the the top of the forum is 'is this an EFFECTIVE way to protest the war'. If you think it is, then tell me why. I don't think these parents realize that there's really no difference between what they're doing by protesting recruiters, and going out on the battlefield and protesting at the soldiers there. Both are simply doing their duty.

 
 
 Yes, it is an effective way to protest the war. We recently had a similar question come up in our local school district, namely should recruiters be allowed. The problem is that federal funding is tied to allowing recruiters access to your students. We did the same thing that seatlle did. We decided to allow recruiters, but to give anti-recruitment groups equal access. The anti-recruitment group in our area is not even anti war. Theya re former soldiers who object to the recruitment based on the fact that the army recruiters esentially lie and the kids end up getting screwed in the end (i.e the education and training provided is worthless outside of the military, less than half of promised bonuses actualy get paid, etc..)
 
 Recruiters ended up voluntarily pulling out of the schools becuase recruitment for our area dropped to 0 (not kidding, 0, as in none, nada).
Kronus

I don't think these parents realize that there's really no difference between what they're doing by protesting recruiters, and going out on the battlefield and protesting at the soldiers there. Both are simply doing their duty.

 
 This is a horrible insult to our troops in the field. Their duty is to fight, and possibly die, for their country. A recruiter's duty is to get X number of kids to sign up each month. To equate the two is to do our fighting soldiers a huge disservice.
unkerpaulie

its good for the army to recruit young people to serve to protect the country. its bad for the army to recruit young people to go to war in iraq. people realise that the army is not using its young people to protect the country, but rather to invade iraq. this is wrong. its a violation of the oaths that every soldier swears to uphold. and people that realize this have the right to do everything in their power to prevent the young people of the community from being misled
jyoshu

Yes, it is an effective way to protest the war. We recently had a similar question come up in our local school district, namely should recruiters be allowed. The problem is that federal funding is tied to allowing recruiters access to your students. 

 
 But why shouldn't anti-war protests be directed at Washington instead of soldiers?
 
 
This is a horrible insult to our troops in the field. Their duty is to fight, and possibly die, for their country. A recruiter's duty is to get X number of kids to sign up each month. To equate the two is to do our fighting soldiers a huge disservice.

 
 I don't think it's any insult to say that at all. I think both are examples of people following orders, and therefore doing their duty for their country. Not everyone gets to go into combat, and a lot of recruiters HAVE been in combat anyway. I think it's a lot more insulting to our servicepeople to direct invective at them, who are just doing their duty, than at Washington where the protest should be directed.
simone

The draft should be reinstated. However, the draft should first fall upon the shoulders of the children of those who start wars. After these folks have shouldered their responsibilities for starting wars there should be a public debate as to whether or not the children of those who do not favor a particular war or who have not particularly supported going into war should be drafted as well.
georged

The draft should be reinstated. However, the draft should first fall upon the shoulders of the children of those who start wars. After these folks have shouldered their responsibilities for starting wars there should be a public debate as to whether or not the children of those who do not favor a particular war or who have not particularly supported going into war should be drafted as well.

simone

Gonna be tough to get chickenhawks to send their kids to war. According to what I read, Cheney himself had five deferments.
Indeed he did.

But why shouldn't anti-war protests be directed at Washington instead of soldiers?

 
 That is ineffective because we no longer have a government that cares abotu representing the people. Cutting off their supply of troops is extremely effective. Without manpower they cannot fight their war. This puts them in a position of either ending it, or drafting people, which would likely lead to such public outrage that the war would die anyway.
 
 These people are not protesting the soldiers, they are protesting the recruitment.

Without manpower they cannot fight their war. This puts them in a position of either ending it, or drafting people, which would likely lead to such public outrage that the war would die anyway.
 
 These people are not protesting the soldiers, they are protesting the recruitment.

 
 Especially when government isolates itself with legislation defining freedom of assembly as a remote location where they won't be disturbed by citizenry opposed to their policy. Being criminally convicted of protesting without a permit at the White House is freedom? I thought 'we' owned that facility?
 Bush, Cheney and Rummy now make their 'public' appearances at secure military bases complete with network feeds and zero civilians. 
 
 Recruiting will become far more difficult when the standard recruiting pitch becomes 'want a job that will make you extremely unpopular?'. Many people forget or are unaware of public frustration levels during the Vietnam era.

Any way used to protest a war is effective. As if we would actully believe anything fox news has to say. I perfer this one http://www.fauxnewschannel.com/

Seems as effective a way I can think of to stop the kids around from signing up, its a method with immediate, practical results.

jyoshu

That is ineffective because we no longer have a government that cares abotu representing the people. Cutting off their supply of troops is extremely effective. Without manpower they cannot fight their war. This puts them in a position of either ending it, or drafting people, which would likely lead to such public outrage that the war would die anyway.
 
 These people are not protesting the soldiers, they are protesting the recruitment.

 
 So IOW, we're going from protesting in one ineffective place, to protesting in another ineffective place. You can't possibly believe that people can make any headway in stopping the war in Iraq by confronting soldiers. If stopping recruitment were the goal of these protesters, they wouldn't feel the need to make the soldiers hear their protests and take it out on them. They would simply try to persuade the schools to block recruiting efforts. 
 
 As far as cutting off our suppy of troops as a country, that isn't going to happen, and even if it did, it wouldn't require any immediate pullout from Iraq. The total deployable number of military personel right now is around 975,000, and we have around 180,000 in Iraq. I think sometimes people think we have most of our forces there, and it's just not true. We have less that a fifth of our deployable forces there.
 
 Furthermore, the strategy of cutting off our supply of troops as a way to protest the war in Iraq would be a very dangerous tactic if it did work. Iraq or not, we NEED military personel for basic national defense. If that tactic did work (which it won't), we'd be jeopardizing other areas of military need that were legitimate, not just the Iraq occupation.
daewoo

So IOW, we're going from protesting in one ineffective place, to protesting in another ineffective place. You can't possibly believe that people can make any headway in stopping the war in Iraq by confronting soldiers. If stopping recruitment were the goal of these protesters, they wouldn't feel the need to make the soldiers hear their protests and take it out on them. They would simply try to persuade the schools to block recruiting efforts. 

 
 If schools ban recruiters, they loose federal aid. This is pretty much bad for everybody. If recruiters do not visit the schools, the schools still get their federal aid.
 
 
As far as cutting off our suppy of troops as a country, that isn't going to happen, and even if it did, it wouldn't require any immediate pullout from Iraq. The total deployable number of military personel right now is around 975,000, and we have around 180,000 in Iraq. I think sometimes people think we have most of our forces there, and it's just not true. We have less that a fifth of our deployable forces there.

 
 Recruitement is down nearly 60%, and the 975,000 number of deployable troops must have been passed on by somebody suffering through crack cocain withdrawal. We only have 150,000 combat troops. The rest are all support staff. Of that 975,000 troops, over 300,000 are office staff.
 
 We have over 80% of our COMBAT forces there, and that is the only number that actually matters. It does not matter how many support personal (mechanics, cooks, paper pushers, REMFs) you have in theater unless you have combat troops there for them to support.
 
 
 
Furthermore, the strategy of cutting off our supply of troops as a way to protest the war in Iraq would be a very dangerous tactic if it did work. Iraq or not, we NEED military personel for basic national defense. If that tactic did work (which it won't), we'd be jeopardizing other areas of military need that were legitimate, not just the Iraq occupation.

 
 Bull. Our best defens is, and always has been, the fact that we have a huge ocean on each side of us. We only have 4 bases that are actually classified as "defensive" bases, and fewert han 100,000 troops, including support, are manning those bases in any type of defensive capacity. The simple fact of the matter is that America is so baig, and so remote when considering the location of any potential enemies, that an invasion or any tuype of sustained attack would be so expansive in terms of manpower, not to mention a logistical nightmare, that the very idea is foolish. we could scale our military back to the size of Canadas and still haev ample defenses for the US.
 
 We have been using our milirtary as atrade negotiation tool in the name of "defense" and using it to prop up our non productive economy for so long in the name of "defense" that people are actually startign to buy into that complete and utter BS. Only an absolute fool could possibly believe that we need the worlds largest military to protect ourselves from Canada and Mexico, nd in the real world, theya re the only countries in a postion to threatent he US directly. Even the soviet union at the height of their power, when they outmanned us in military forces 2-1 in both men and equipment never had any type of invasion plan for the US. It is simply rediculous to even imagine such a thing.
jyoshu

Recruitement is down nearly 60%, and the 975,000 number of deployable troops must have been passed on by somebody suffering through crack cocain withdrawal.

 
 Only if you think the CBO is on crack.
 
 
It does not matter how many support personal (mechanics, cooks, paper pushers, REMFs) you have in theater unless you have combat troops there for them to support.

 
 Of course, but this is beside the point. Of the 180,000 troops that are there now, many of them are support staff as well. Even if you take the number of deployable combat troops, we are nowhere near 80% usage, as you claim. 180,000 is less that 50% of 420,000, which is the number of deployable combat troops. But even then it's less than that, because of the 180,000 in Iraq, not all of those are combat troops either. You need to review CBO numbers sometime. 
 
 
Bull. Our best defens is, and always has been, the fact that we have a huge ocean on each side of us. 

 
 Dude, this isn't the era of the Spanish armada or clipper sailing ships. It's the 21st century. The fact we are surrounded by oceans means very little in today's day and time when air power, air transportation, paratrooping, etc. is a primary medium. A coordinated air, sea, and missile strike could certainly be effective.
 
 
We have been using our milirtary as atrade negotiation tool in the name of "defense" and using it to prop up our non productive economy for so long

 
 So? That in itself is a valuable tool.
simone

Wow, we have a lot of Kool Aid drinkers here.
 
 "Fox News is biased blah blah blah". Please, get a grip and stop listening to moveon.org and Michael Moore.

The fact we are surrounded by oceans means very little in today's day and time when air power, air transportation, paratrooping, etc. is a primary medium.  Sure it does. Paratrooping? Are you on crack? Do you have any idea how many paratroops it would take to establish a beach head in the US? You are looking at 100,000 troops, minimum. Considering the fact that a jump rigged starlifter only provides jump facilities for 100 men, that seems pretty unlikely a scenario. It would take tens of thousands of flights utilizing massive, unarmed aircraft making drops over the continental united states. 
 
 Air transportation, especially across an ocean, is far, FAR, too expensive to utilize for an invasion of that size. I don't think that a missile strike is really somethign we are likely to see, since the entire world knows that our response to a ballistic missile attack is a counter attack using nuclear weapons before the enemy attack even hits the ground.
 
 There is simply no reasonable means for an invasion of the United States. 
 
 
So? That in itself is a valuable tool.

 
 If you are really comfortable with the tens or hundreds of thousands of civlians deaths over the years to ensure that coca cola has trade superiority in other countries and to ensure that American manufacturers have exemption from child labor, workplace safety, and minimum wage laws, more power to you I suppose. Unfortunatly that is the kind of thing that tends to roll back around and bite you in the butt (google "9/11 attacks") besides being horribly and rediculously expensive.

I have zero contact with MoveOn. I've only seen one Michael Moore movie. Guess it really scares you when people think for themselves instead of following your pweshious party line as dictated by Karl Rove. Or Pat Robertson. Or Jerry Falwell.

 
 Same here and I've never seen a Moore movie or listened to talk radio. Individual thinking is not encouraged by the the current, desperate administration.
jyoshu

If you are really comfortable with the tens or hundreds of thousands of civlians deaths over the years to ensure

 
 The issue of military size and number of deaths in Iraq are two different things. Maintaining a large military does not mean there will be civilian deaths. If you feel we need a smaller military, what would be the ideal size, in your opinion?
daewoo

The issue of military size and number of deaths in Iraq are two different things. Maintaining a large military does not mean there will be civilian deaths. If you feel we need a smaller military, what would be the ideal size, in your opinion?

 
 I was not talking abotu Iraqi civilian deaths. Those are not, IMO, trade related. 
 
 Ideal size? Scale it back to strictly defensive numbers. In the real world, 300,000 total troops is MORE than enough to defend the United States. The trick there is that they have to BE in the united states in order to defend it. 
 
 our military leading up to WWI was incredibly small. We still managed to mobilize and fight the war when the time came. Following WWI, we disbanded the vast majority of the military. In the run up to WWII we once again had an undersized military. We still managed to mobilize to fight WWII. 
 
 That was more or less the point of the militia portions of the constitution. It was meant to be a replacement to a standing military, since it was widely accepted (and frankly has been proven 100% correct) that a standing military is a threat to peace.

I fail to understand why many Americans encourage politicians to enable a large standing military strung out all over the world that we simply can't afford. I would think their insecurities should be placated by the fact we can almost instantly destroy any nation in the world attacking us without the use of troops.

They live in houses made out of cardboard and sawdust, are up to their eyeballs in debt, and are scared to death of anything that threatens their way of life (though why somebody would want to live like that is far beyond my comprehension). I think that having large numbers of men with guns runnign around working in their "best iterests" is very comforting to the sheeple. 
 
 On top of that, I do not think that most americans DO mind the fact that we have used our military to ensure trade dominance, even if it is by turning children into virtual slaves, installing tyrants and dictators, and killing off the competition. At the end of the day, americans tend to be rather selfish. Sure they are willing to donate a few bucks to a relief fund for a natural disater, but there is no way they are going to take a 20% cost of living hit just because their current level of comfort is built on the misery of millions. 
 
 
 We have reached a diffiuclt point now where some of those millions are hitting back. IF you look at actions like this traditionally, the reality of the matter is that as time goes by, the anti american forces will become more organized and larger. There are anti american militant groups all of the world, the arabs are just he first ones to strike. It will not be long before they have formed alliances with similar groups in Asia, S America, and the former soviet union. Then we are screwed, especially the middle class, unless we resort to a police state to maintain order, which leads to a whole different set of problems.
